All upcoming events will be listed at [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/) August 28, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: Be Prepared this Fall and Winter: Respiratory Illnesses Whether it is the Flu, RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus) or COVID-19 most respiratory viruses happen year-round in the U.S, there is usually more activity during the fall and winter season. Take everyday preventative actions to stop the spread of germs: - Wash your hands frequently with soap for at least 20 seconds and then rinse them under running water. - If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand rub. - Don't touch your face with your hands after touching something that has germs on it. - Don't drink out of cups or bottles that others have used. - Get vaccinated to help reduce the risk of illness. If you are sick, you can do the following to help protect others: - Stay home and wear a mask if you are around others. - Use a paper tissue or your elbow to cover your nose and mouth when you cough or sneeze. - Talk to your local health provider. Stay Updated Visit the Centers for Disease Control and Disease Prevention (CDC) [respiratory virus updates](https://www.cdc.gov/respiratory-viruses/whats-new/index.html) page to learn more about new updates during respiratory illness season every week. PWHD Opioid Community Member Engagement Survey Help the Prince William Health District end the opioid epidemic! Have you or a loved one been impacted by opioid addiction? August 21, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: Children's Eye Health and Safety Month Healthy Vision Starts with You! August reminds us to protect and care for our eye's health. Keep these tips in mind to take care of your eyes. - Eat right to protect your sight. Eye-healthy foods include dark leafy greens like spinach, kale, and collard greens. - Speak up if your vision changes. - Wear your glasses. - Always wash your hands before putting them close to your eyes. - Wear sunglasses that block 99% or 100% of the sun's rays. - Give your eyes a break and follow the 20/20/20 rule: - Every 20 minutes, look about 20 feet away for 20 seconds. - If you smoke, make a quit plan. - Start your journey by calling 1-800- [Quit-Now](https://quitnowvirginia.org/)(1-800-784-8669). For more information, please visit the National Eye Institute's [Healthy Vision](https://www.nei.nih.gov/learn-about-eye-health/healthy-vision) page. Human breast milk is the only food that infants need for the first six months of life, and they can receive all the nutrition they need through it. There are many health benefits that arise from breastfeeding, as the cells, hormones, and antibodies in breastmilk help to protect babies from illness. While the rate of protection is different for everyone, research shows that babies who were breastfed have a lower risk of certain illnesses. We have listed some below: - Asthma - Leukemia (during childhood) - Obesity (during childhood) - Ear infections - Eczema - Diarrhea and vomiting - Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) - Type 2 diabetes While there are many benefits to breastfeeding, it's important to consider what factors may play a role in the decision on whether or not to breastfeed. Read more at [Women's Health](https://www.womenshealth.gov/breastfeeding/) Breastfeeding [resources page](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/breastfeeding/resources/). All upcoming events will be listed at [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/) August 7, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know : Severe Weather Preparedness Tips & Resources Tips to Keep in Mind - If local officials tell you to evacuate, do so immediately! - Have pre-planned evacuation routes - consider hotels, fuel, family members with a disability, pet accommodations etc. - Have 1 gallon of water per person per day and 3 days or more supply of food (don't forget extra for the pets!) - regardless of evacuation. - Have medications and important documents close by - in most cases, you will have to show identification for shelter access. - Stay tuned to local radio weather alerts throughout and after the hurricane to find resources near you. More information at [https://www.ready.gov/severe-weather](https://www.ready.gov/severe-weather) Stay Informed It is recommended to sign up for alerts where you live and work. [NOAA Radio](https://www.weather.gov/nwr/)(NWR) - A nationwide network of radio stations that broadcast continuous weather information from the nearest National Weather Service office based on your physical location. [FEMA Mobile App](http://www.ready.gov/fema-app)- Receive real-time weather and emergency alerts, send notifications to loved ones, locate emergency shelters in your area, get preparedness strategies and more. - Sign Up for Local Alerts & Warnings August 4, 2023 Prince William Health District Community Outreach Events - Monday August 7th - Tuesday August 8th from 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. - Woodbridge [Global Welcome Center,](https://www.pwcs.edu/departments/global_welcome_center/index)15111 Blackburn Rd, Woodbridge, VA 22191 - PWHD is attending to provide information on Health District services and resources. - Thursday, August 10th from 4:00 p.m. - 7:00 p.m. [PWCS Summer Community Event](https://www.pwcs.edu/community_event), Unity Braxton Middle School, 10100 Lomond Dr. Manassas, VA 20109 - PWHD is attending to provide information on Health District services and resources. - Friday, August 11th from 9:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. [PWCCF Community Back-to-Event](https://b2s.pwccfoundation.org/)(2 locations!) - Unity Braxton Middle School, 10100 VA 20109 - Freedom High School, 15201 Neabsco Mills Rd. All upcoming events will be listed at [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/) July 31, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: Health Director Farewell & National Immunization Awareness Farewell Dr. Allison Ansher, Health Director of Prince William Health District (PWHD) will retire on August 1, 2023, with 30 years of dedicated service with VDH. She started her public health career in PWHD in women's health and was instrumental in developing and directing our Tuberculosis program. Under her leadership, the PWHD Team has had many accomplishments. We have listed some of her many impactful achievements below. - Served as Acting Health Director from 2004 -2006 while the Health Director at that time served time overseas. Dr. Ansher formally became Health Director in 2006. - Was the driving force behind the district's efforts to become a nationally accredited health department (awarded on August 17, 2016) and is working hard to ensure a successful reaccreditation submission this year - no small feat as the PWHD recovers from pandemic disruptions to staffing and operations. - Was co-chair and one of the founding members of the Community Healthcare Coalition of Greater Prince William which leads our local community health assessments and the community health improvement plan efforts. - Is an active participant in the George Mason College of Health and Human Services Advisory Board, the Metropolitan Council of Government Health Officers Committee and Mason and Partners Advisory Board. - Worked tirelessly during the COVID-19 pandemic with community leaders and the faith community to ensure disparities in COVID care and vaccination efforts were addressed. - Has written and received multiple grants, written publications, and received several awards for her service to the community. - Most recent publication a collaboration with CDC published in the Journal of Racial and Ethnic Health Disparities - [Mitigating SARS-CoV-2 Transmission in Hispanic and Latino Communities-Prince William Health District, Virginia, June 2020](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7860999/) - Awards include Prince William County (PWC) Executive's award, PWC Safety Award, and as a partner with George Mason University the Chamber of Commerce Innovative Practice of the Year: Mason and Partners Clinics (MAP) award. - Most recent publication a collaboration with CDC published in the Journal of Racial and Ethnic Health Disparities - We wish Dr. Ansher all the best in her future endeavors and thank her for her many years of service. Dr. Obasanjo will be the acting Health Director of Prince William Health District. Immunization Awareness As July is coming to a close, it's time to get ready for the start of the school year. August is National Immunization Awareness Month! This annual observance is held in August to highlight the importance of routine vaccination for people of all ages. Before the first bell rings, let's review what routine childhood immunizations do: 1. Prevent serious diseases. 2. Protect communities. 3. Teach your child's immune system to fight specific diseases. 4. Are safe and effective. Vaccines are available through your pediatrician, pharmacies, and your [local health department.](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/locations/) For more information, visit the Virginia Department of Health's [Back to School](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/backtoschool/) page. All upcoming events will be listed at [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/) July 24, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: World Hepatitis Day 'We're not waiting', this Friday, July 28th is [World Hepatitis Day](https://www.worldhepatitisday.org/). This year's theme centers on the urgent need for testing and treatment of Hepatitis for people who need it. Did you know? Hepatitis means inflammation of the liver. When the liver is inflamed or damaged, it's function can become affected. Hepatitis, however, is often caused by a virus. The common types of viral hepatitis are: - Hepatitis A - Hepatitis B - Hepatitis C According to the [Centers for Disease and Prevention (CDC),](https://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis/abc/index.htm#:~:text=Who%20should%20be%20tested%3F) all adults aged 18 and older should be tested for Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C at least once in their lifetime. Learn in more detail what each type of viral hepatitis means, how it spreads, who should be vaccinated, tested, and treatment by visiting the Virginia Department of Health's Viral [Hepatitis](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/disease-prevention/disease-prevention/viral-hepatitis/) page. All upcoming events will be listed at [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/health-district-events/) July 17, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: UV Safety July is UV safety awareness month! Protecting your skin from ultraviolet (UV) rays is important all year round. UV rays can come from the sun, tanning beds, and sunlamps. Even on cloudy and cool days, UV rays can reflect off surfaces like water, cement, sand, and snow. Did you know? Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the U.S. Most skin cancers are caused by too much exposure to UV light and are the most common cancer in the U.S. Sun safety is easy: - Stay in shade when possible. - Stay inside when the sun is the brightest. - Use broad-spectrum sunscreen with a sun-protection factor (SPF) of at least 30 and reapply frequently. - Wear a hat, long sleeves, and sunglasses. Resources The [UV Index](https://enviro.epa.gov/envirofacts/uv/search) predicts the strength of UV rays each day in your area and offers safety tips on how to protect your skin. July is dedicated to bringing awareness to the current state of mental health and promote the many ways to improve it. Did you know? Access to and the quality of healthcare before, during, and after pregnancy can affect health outcomes in the future. Resources Paying attention and taking care of your emotional health is just as important as your physical health. Steps you can take in keeping optimal mental and physical wellness are to create a plan, get prenatal and postnatal care. The Virginia Department of Health (VDH) and other health organization offer a wide range of resources and information for: [Pregnancy](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/pregnancy/) [Family planning](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/family-planning/) [WIC](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/wic/)(Women, Health Hotline](https://mchb.hrsa.gov/national-maternal-mental-health-hotline): 1-833-TLC-MAMA (1-833-852-6262) Prince William Health District Community Outreach Events - Monday July 10th - Tuesday July 11th from 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. - Manassas [Global Welcome Center](https://www.pwcs.edu/departments/global_welcome_center/index), 10100 Lomond Dr, Manassas, VA 20109 - PWHD is attending to provide information on Health District services and resources. - Wednesday July 12th - Thursday July 13th from 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. - Woodbridge [Global Welcome Center,](https://www.pwcs.edu/departments/global_welcome_center/index)15111 Blackburn Rd, Woodbridge, VA 22191 - PWHD is attending to provide information on Health District services and resources. - Saturday July 15, from 9:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. (This event will be outdoors) - Dale City Christian Church Picnic Extravaganza 14022 Lindendale Road, Woodbridge, VA 22193 - Visit [https://dccccofpraise.org/](https://dccccofpraise.org/)for more information. More information about all other upcoming events will be listed at [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/prince-william-health-district-events/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/prince-william/prince-william-health-district-events/) PWHD Update Information Posted Monday PWHD Website: July 3, 2023 All Prince William Health District Offices and Clinics Will Be Closed Tomorrow, July 4, 2023, in Observance of Independence Day The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: Grilling Safety Food safety is always important! If you are grilling for the Fourth of July or anytime this summer, let's review steps for a safe and fun grilling season. When you handle raw meat, poultry, and seafood remember to: - Separate - When shopping, pick up meat, poultry, and seafood last and separate them from other food in your shopping cart and grocery bags. - Refrigerate - Keep food chilled until ready to grill. If you are using a cooler to move the food keep it at a temperature of 40 °F. - Wash hands - Use soap and water to clean hands before and after handling food. - Cook - Use a food thermometer, if possible, to ensure the meat is hot enough to kill harmful germs. - Don't cross contaminate - Throw out marinades and sauces that have touched raw meat juices. Put cooked meat on a clean plate. - Refrigerate - Put leftovers in tightly covered containers within 2 hours of cooking. More information on grilling and safe cooking temperatures can be found at [https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/bbq-iq.html](https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/bbq-iq.html) Grilling Safety Facts &Tips - July is the peak month for grill fires. - Propane and charcoal BBQ grills should only be used outdoors. - Keep children and pets at least three feet away from grill area. - Keep your grill clean. - Never leave your grill unattended. - The grill should be placed well away from the home, deck railings and out from under eaves and overhanging branches. There are many things we can do to beat the heat this summer. Prepare for Extreme Heat Warnings! Extreme heat is a long period (2 to 3 days) of high heat and humidity with a temperature of 90 degrees or more. They can happen without warning. What Can We Do? - Find places in our community where we can go to get cool. - Keep your home cool by doing the following: - Cover windows with drapes or shades. - Weather strip doors and windows. - Use attic fans to clear the hot air. - Learn the signs of heat-related illness. Read more preparation tips here: [www.vaemergency.gov/threats/extreme-heat](http://www.vaemergency.gov/threats/extreme-heat) What Are the Signs of Heat-Related Illness? - Heat Cramps: Muscle spasms or pains in the stomach arms, or legs. - Heat exhaustion: Heavy sweating, paleness, muscle cramps, tiredness, nausea, headache or vomiting or fainting. - Heat stroke: Very high body temperature (above 103 degrees); red, hot, and dry skin with no sweat; fast pulse; dizziness; confusions; or unconsciousness. If heat cramp and exhaustion symptoms get worse get medical help. For heat stroke symptoms call 911 or take the person to the hospital right away. What Can We Do to Prevent Heat-Related Illness? - Drink plenty of water. - Choose lightweight, loose-fitting clothing. - Stay cool indoors. - Never leave children in cars. - Limit the time spent outside to when it is the coolest. - Check for local weather updates for extreme heat alerts. - Keep your pets hydrated and in a shaded area. Animals can also be affected by the hot weather. Ticks are arachnids that can spread diseases to humans, pets, and wildlife. It is important to take steps to: . Prevent tick bites. . Learn how to locate, remove, and monitor any tick bites. Protect Yourself from Tick Illnesses: . Check body and clothing for ticks after being outdoors. . Use EPA-registered Insect Repellent. . Tuck your pant legs into your socks for best practice tick prevention. . Use a tick prevention product for your pet as recommended by a veterinarian. Tick removal information is available at: [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/ticks/tick-removal/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/ticks/tick-removal/) Tick identification information is available at: [https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/ticks/tick-identification/](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/ticks/tick-identification/) The National Maternal Mental Health Hotline number has changed! 1-833-TLC-MAMA or (1-833-852-6262) The National Maternal Hotline provides a 24/7 lifeline with: . Free confidential support and resources for pregnant and new mothers in English and Spanish. . Interpreter services in 60 languages. . Referrals to local and telehealth providers and support groups . Culturally sensitive support . Response within a few minutes, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week Did you know? The hotline recently celebrated its first birthday this past Mother's Day and provided support to over 12,000 people that called or text messaged. The month-long observance aims to educate the public about the importance of mental health, promote mental health resources and support services, and encourage everyone to prioritize their mental well-being. Remember, mental health is just as important as physical health, and taking care of our mental well-being is crucial for leading a fulfilling life. It is important to recognize that it is okay to seek appropriate help and support. Need Help? - If you or someone you know is struggling or in crisis, help is available. Call or text 988 or chat 988lifeline.org. - To learn how to get support for mental health, drug, and alcohol issues, visit FindSupport.gov. - To locate treatment facilities or providers, visit FindTreatment.gov or call SAMHSA's National Helpline at 800-662-HELP (4357). They work tirelessly to improve the health and well-being of all community members often going above and beyond to ensure their comfort and safety. This week, we honor and thank all the public health nurses who have made a difference in the lives of so many. Thank you for your unwavering commitment to the nursing profession and of those you serve. In Virginia, every year more than 16,000 Virginians have a new stroke. A stroke is also known as a brain attack and can occur when the blood supply to the brain is blocked or a blood vessel in the brain bursts. An easy way to spot common signs of a stroke is by remembering to use the F.A.S.T acronym and call 911! Apply these steps for others and yourself if possible. - F = Face drooping: Ask the person to smile. Does one side droop? - A = Arm weakness: Ask the person to raise both their arms. Does one arm drifts downward? - S = Speech difficulty: Ask the person to repeat a simple sentence. Are the words slurred, do they understand? - T = Time to call 911: If the person shows any of these signs, call 9-1-1 immediately. Stroke treatment can begin in the ambulance. Other stroke signs may include sudden trouble with: - Walking or balance. - Seeing. - Weak or numb on one side of body. Remember: Call 911 even for ONE SIGN. Call 911 even if SIGNS STOP. Hurricane Preparedness Week (April 30th - May 6th) The best time to prepare for hurricanes is BEFORE hurricane season begins. Avoid having to rush through potentially life-saving preparations by waiting until it's too late. This week alongside the National Oceanic Atmospheric Demonstration (NOAA) we are spreading the word on how to: - Prepare before hurricane season. - Understand forecast information. - Get moving when a storm threatens. - Stay protected during storms. - Use caution after storms. - Take action today. The Virginia Department of Health (VDH) has implemented the new guidance from the CDC effective immediately. What is the updated guidance? - Monovalent (original) COVID-19 mRNA vaccines are no longer authorized for use in the U.S. - CDC recommends that everyone ages 6 years and older receive a bivalent mRNA COVID-19 vaccine, regardless of whether they previously completed their (monovalent) primary series. - Individuals ages 6 years and older who have already received a bivalent mRNA vaccine do not need to take any action unless they are 65 years or older or immunocompromised. - For young children, multiple doses continue to be recommended and will vary by age, vaccine, and which vaccines were previously received. - CDC recommendations allow an additional bivalent vaccine dose for adults aged 65 years and older and additional bivalent doses for people who are immunocompromised. If needed, this additional COVID-19 vaccine dose should be administered at least four months after their initial bivalent dose. Recognizing the Greater Prince William Medical Reserve Corps (MRC) April 16 - 22 is National Volunteer Week! Thank you to the 1,000 Greater Prince William Medical Reserve Corps (MRC) volunteers who donate their skills, expertise, and time to support ongoing public health initiatives and health emergencies throughout our community. Who is the MRC? The MRC is a force of dedicated volunteers who stand ready to support the community in the event of a public health emergency. MRC volunteers are community members, with diverse skill sets, backgrounds and experiences who are committed to improving public health and community resilience. The greater Prince William community has an active and dedicated MRC unit with over 1,000 volunteers. Snapshot of 2022 In 2022, a total of 224 volunteers served more than 1,960 hours in activities and training to support public health initiatives, including COVID and flu vaccination clinics, education and outreach, health department administrative support and more! Interested in volunteering with the MRC? You never know when your community might need you. New volunteers are always welcome! Medical expertise or training is not required. It is to raise awareness about STI prevention, testing, treatment, and how they can impact our lives. About 1 in 5 persons in the United States have an STI. Like many other states, Virginia has seen an increase in STIs however there are steps we can all take to help address this public health problem. What Can You Do? We can all protect ourselves and each other by following these three steps: talk, test, and treat. - Talking With Your Partner(s) Talking with your partner(s) about your health and practicing safe behaviors is important because it can help protect you from STIs before having sex. - Why Should I Test? Most STIs do not have symptoms but they can still cause health problems. - Are STIs Treatable? Having a STI is not the end! Most STIs can be cured, and all are treatable. Prince William Health District Health Services The health district's STI clinic offers: - Screening - Detection - Treatment - Education Please bring your health insurance information and proof of household income for services you receive. Call for more information and/or schedule an appointment: 703-792-6300. Visit VDH Resource Connections for more free or low-cost STI locations near you! This year's theme centered on "Fuel for the Future". Key Messages Eat with the environment in mind: - Enjoy more plant-based meals and snacks. - Purchase foods with minimal packaging. - Buy foods in season and shop locally when possible. - Start a container or backyard garden to grow food at home. See a Registered Dietitian Nutritionist (RDN): - Ask your doctor for a referral to an RDN. - Find an RDN who specializes in your unique needs. - Learn how nutrient needs may change with age. - Receive personalized nutrition information to meet your health goals. Stay nourished and save money: - Plan your meals and snacks. - See what food you have at home before purchasing more. - Use a grocery list and shop sales when purchasing food. - Learn about community resources such as SNAP, WIC and local food banks. Eat a variety of foods from all food groups: - Include your favorite cultural foods and traditions. - Eat foods in various forms including fresh, frozen, canned and dried. - Avoid fad diets that promote unnecessary restrictions. - Practice gratitude for your body by giving it the fuel it needs. Make tasty foods at home: - Learn cooking and meal preparation skills. - Try new flavors and foods from around the world. - Find creative ways to use leftovers rather than tossing them. - Create happy memories by eating with friends and family when possible. Did You Know? On March 24, 1882, Dr. Robert Koch announced the finding of the type of bacteria that causes TB. The bacteria known as Mycobacterium tuberculosis commonly attacks the lungs but can affect the kidneys, spine, or brain. TB bacteria can spread through the air from one person to another. It is important to know that not everyone infected with TB bacteria becomes sick. People who do not have symptoms may have latent TB infection (LTBI) and TB disease. If it is not treated, these conditions can be fatal. More information: [https://www.cdc.gov/tb/default.htm](https://www.cdc.gov/tb/default.htm) Prince William Health District's TB Services Dedicated TB Team The PWHD's TB team is a dedicated group of hardworking people who continue to educate, test, and treat all members of our community. Their work is vital in contributing to the overall health and well-being of Prince William District residents. The TB team provides the following services: Tuberculosis risk assessments for people with - o TB symptoms (fever, night sweats, cough, and weight loss) o Newcomers from countries with high TB rates o Other high-risk groups Tuberculosis testing: tuberculin skin tests and blood tests (IGRA) Tuberculin Risk Assessment with tuberculin skin testing if indicated for school. Chest X-Ray and treatment recommendations for positive TB test individuals. Diagnosis, treatment, case management or co-management with private doctors for all active and suspected cases of TB. Evaluation of individuals exposed to a case of active TB. As everyone set their clocks 1 hour forward, this may be a good time to check your smoke alarms. See emergency preparedness tips below: - Twice a year: Test your smoke alarms. - Once a year: Check to see if your alarm needs new batteries. - Review and restock your emergency supplies. More safety tips: [https://www.ready.gov/](https://www.ready.gov/) March is National Kidney Month Did you know? 90% of U.S. Adults who have chronic kidney disease do not know their kidneys are damaged. Kidney disease is known as the "silent disease" because there are usually no symptoms at the early stages. The earlier you find out if you have kidney disease the sooner you can take steps to protect the health of your kidneys. What Can I Do to Keep My Kidneys Healthy? Know Your Risk Even if you feel healthy, if you are over 60 or have risk factors like: - High blood pressure - Heart disease - Diabetes Consider talking with your doctor or health care professional team about getting tested for kidney disease. They will use two fast tests to check for kidney disease. A urine test can check for damage, and a blood test can check how well your kidneys are in getting rid of wastes from your blood. Practice Healthy Moments You can protect your kidneys by preventing or managing health conditions that can cause kidney damage such as diabetes and high blood pressure. Other healthy tips include: - Healthy Food Choices: o Fresh fruits, frozen vegetables, whole grains, and low fat or dairy free foods. - Adding physical activity to your routine. - A good night rest: o Aim for 7 to 8 hours of sleep each night. - Stop smoking: o Take steps by calling 1-800-QUIT-NOW or 1-800-784-8669 o More information: [Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) - NIDDK (nih.gov)](https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/kidney-disease/chronic-kidney-disease-ckd) Prince William Health District Mobile Clinic Unit is Offering the Covid-19 and Flu Vaccine - Tuesday March 14, from 11:30 a.m. - 6:00 p.m. (This clinic will be indoors). - Todos Neighborhood Market 16593 River Ridge Blvd, Woodbridge, VA 22191 - Vaccines offered for ages 5 years and older: Pfizer & Moderna (including boosters), according to current recommendations - While vaccine supplies last. - No appointments are required. COVID-19 at-home test kits available (as supplies last) PWHD Update Information 6, 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know: March is Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month Colorectal Cancer Screening Colorectal cancer almost always develops from abnormal growths. These growths in the colon or rectum are known as precancerous polyps. A screening test which is used to look for disease when a person does not have symptoms can find these precancerous polyps. If found, they can be removed before they turn into cancer. Also, a screening test can find colorectal cancer early which is when treatment works best. Screening is key to preventing cancer. You can learn about the several types of colorectal screening tests at [http://bit.ly/3Yr15C2](http://bit.ly/3Yr15C2) How Often Should I Get Screened and Why? It is recommended that adults at age 45 should begin screening for colorectal cancer. Screening should then continue at regular intervals until age 75. It's important to get screened because colorectal polyps and colorectal cancer do not always cause symptoms at first. Talk with your health care professional team or doctor if you think you may be at an increased risk for colorectal cancer about: When to begin screening. Which test is right for you. COVID-19 at-home test kits available (as supplies last) PWHD Update Information 2023 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know Norovirus Illness What is it? Norovirus illness is sometimes called the stomach flu or stomach bug. It is the most common cause of vomiting and diarrhea. Persons of all ages can get infected and sick with it. Although a common virus, norovirus is not related to the flu which is caused by influenza virus. How Norovirus Spreads Norovirus can spread easily and fast in many ways. The most common way to spread and get infected with norovirus is by accidently getting tiny particles of feces (poop), or vomit from an infected person in your mouth. This can happen if you: - Eat food or drink liquids that are contaminated with norovirus - Touch surfaces or objects contaminated with norovirus and then put your fingers in your mouth - Have direct contact with someone who is infected with norovirus, such as by caring for them or sharing food or eating utensils with them. Symptoms A person usually develops symptoms 12 to 48 hours after being exposed. This can lead to dehydration, especially in young children, older adults, and people with other illnesses. The most common symptoms are: - Diarrhea - Vomiting - Nausea - Stomach pain Prevention Help protect yourself and others by following helpful tips listed below. Practice proper handwashing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds: - After using the toilet or changing diapers. - Before eating, preparing, or handling food. - Before giving yourself or someone else medicine. Clean and disinfect surfaces: - Routinely clean and sanitize kitchen utensils, counters, and surfaces before preparing food. - After someone vomits or has diarrhea put on rubber or disposable gloves to clean and disinfect surface areas immediately. Read more [About Norovirus | CDC.](https://www.cdc.gov/norovirus/about/index.html#:~:text=Norovirus%20is%20sometimes%20called%20the%20stomach%20flu%20or%20stomach%20bug.) Why This Matters Women, Black or Hispanic adults who experience cardiac arrest outside a hospital setting are for the most part less likely to receive lifesaving care from a bystander. About 90% of people who experience a cardiac arrest outside a hospital die. CPR if done at once can double or triple a person's chance of survival (AHA). What Is Hands-Only CPR? Consists of two steps: 1. Call 911 2. Push Hard and Fast If you are interested in learning how to preform hands-only CPR, there are readily available study and video resources on the [ AHA's training page.](https://cpr.heart.org/en/cpr-courses-and-kits/hands-only-cpr) According to the AHA, training is important and if you can get trained please do so, but you do not need to have a certification in CPR to perform CPR that may save a life. Persons with or without insurance can search for no-cost COVID-19 testing at Increasing Community Access to Testing (ICATT) locations nearest to them and make an appointment. ICATT locations include participating pharmacies, commercial laboratory sites, community sites, and retail locations. Who should get tested at these locations? Key times to get tested: If you have symptoms, test immediately. If you were exposed to COVID-19 and do not have symptoms, wait at least 5 full days after your exposure before testing. If you test too early, you may be more likely to get an inaccurate result. Types of COVID-19 tests offered at these locations The types of tests offered vary by location and provider: Laboratory-based nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) including polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests. Results are usually provided within 24-48 hours. Rapid antigen point-of-care (POC) testing where results are usually available within 15 to 30 minutes. Symptoms of RSV infection usually include: Runny nose Decrease in appetite Coughing Sneezing Fever Wheezing These symptoms usually appear in stages and not all at once. In very young infants with RSV the only symptoms may be irritability, decreased activity, and breathing difficulties. Almost all children will have had an RSV infection by their second birthday. Care Most RSV infections go away on their own in a week or two. There is no specific treatment for RSV infection, though researchers are working to develop vaccines and antivirals (medicines that fight viruses). Take steps to relieve symptoms Manage fever and pain: Over-the-counter fever reducers and pain relievers, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen. (Never give aspirin to children.) Drink enough fluids: It is important for people with RSV infection to drink enough fluids to prevent dehydration (loss of body fluids). Talk to your healthcare provider: Before giving your child nonprescription cold medicines, because some medicines contain ingredients that are not good for children. Immediately call your healthcare professional (s) if you or your child is having difficulty breathing, not drinking enough fluids, or experiencing worsening symptoms. To view the current total number of COVID-19 vaccinations that have been administered in the United States, please visit the CDC COVID Data Tracker. COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective. COVID-19 vaccines were evaluated in tens of thousands of participants in clinical trials. The vaccines met the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA's) rigorous scientific standards for safety, effectiveness, and manufacturing quality needed to support emergency use authorization (EUA). Learn more about EUAs in this video. The Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson/Janssen and Novavax COVID-19 vaccines will continue to undergo the most intensive safety monitoring in US history. This monitoring includes using both established and new safety monitoring systems to make sure that COVID-19 vaccines are safe. Common Side Effects Some people have side effects after getting their COVID-19 vaccine, while others might have no side effects. Side effects may affect the ability to do daily activities, but they should go away within a few days. Learn more about common side effects after COVID-19 vaccination. Adverse Events (Serious Safety Problems) Are Rare In rare cases, people have experienced serious health events after COVID-19 vaccination. Any health problem that happens after vaccination is considered an adverse event. An adverse event can be caused by the vaccine or can be caused by a coincidental event not related to the vaccine, such as an unrelated fever, that happened following vaccination. People should contact their healthcare provider if they have fever, chills, swollen lymph nodes and a new, unexplained rash. People who are diagnosed with monkeypox (mpox) should stay home and avoid close contact with others until the rash has fully resolved, the scabs have fallen off and a fresh layer of intact skin has formed. For most people, infection with mpox is painful but not life threatening. Mpox is a preventable disease that spreads from person to person through close contact. There are things everyone can do to help prevent the spread: Avoid close, skin-to-skin contact with someone with a new, unexplained rash. Do not share cups, utensils, bedding or towels with someone who is sick. Stay home when you are sick. Wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after contact with infected people or animals. Wear a mask in situations where you may have lengthy or close face-to-face contact with people who may be infected. Get vaccinated with the JYNNEOS mpox vaccine, if you are eligible. People who may have been exposed to mpox should receive the vaccine as soon as possible to reduce the chance of developing mpox after exposure. The vaccine is most effective if administered within 4 days of exposure, but it may be administered up to 14 days after exposure. Contact your local health department to see if you are eligible for vaccination and to find out where it is available. Healthcare providers with patients at high risk of severe illness should work with their local health department to facilitate administration of the JYNNEOS vaccine and options for treatment of mpox. For more information, healthcare providers can access the Healthcare Providers website for mpox. VDH has the latest information available to the public at its mpox website. The site also includes information about cases and vaccines administered in Virginia. The VDH call center is another source of information regarding mpox and vaccination and treatment options; call (877) VAX-IN-VA - (877) 829-4682- Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. with assistance in English, Spanish and more than 100 other languages. TTY users may dial 7-1-1. Members of this population will only receive a message if records indicate they are eligible for, but have not yet received, a bivalent booster. The voice/text messages are just one more way VDH is reaching out to let Virginians know they can get a free bivalent booster at many locations, including health care providers, local pharmacies, and health departments around the state. The message will read: "VA Dept of Health records indicate you are eligible for a COVID-19 bivalent booster. Schedule an appt at [https://vase.vdh.virginia.gov](https://vase.vdh.virginia.gov) or (877) 829-4682." Contact information from the resident's immunization record will determine whether they receive a text message (for mobile numbers) or a phone call (for landlines). Individuals do not need to wait for this notification to get a bivalent booster. If you have questions about your eligibility to receive a bivalent booster, or believe you have been contacted in error, please contact the VDH call center for a review of your record. Call 877-VAX-IN-VA (877-829-4682, TTY users call 7-1-1). Assistance is available in English, Spanish, and more than 100 other languages. This is especially important because as temperatures cool, we spend more time indoors with others, and may travel to gather with friends and family for celebrations who are at increased risk of severe complications from infection. Virginia is already seeing [widespread reports](https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/epidemiology/influenza-flu-in-virginia/influenza-surveillance/) of the influenza virus detected in recent weeks. This year's flu season is already showing concerning, early signs that it may be worse than in recent years. More people are seeking care in hospitals and urgent care centers for influenza-like illness than at this point in previous years, particularly young children aged 0-4 years. Virginia health officials encourage everyone aged six months and older to get a flu vaccine this fall, with rare exception. In addition, Virginia is seeing cases of Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). RSV is common and usually causes mild to moderate cold-like symptoms but can be very dangerous for babies, young children or those who are immunocompromised. Emergency department and urgent care visits with diagnosed RSV have been increasing rapidly since early September. Practice preventive health habits to reduce the chance of infection and call your healthcare provider if you or your child is having difficulty breathing, not drinking enough fluids, or experiencing worsening symptoms. There is no vaccine to protect against RSV or many of the other common winter viruses. For further information contact your Health Care Provider. It is not uncommon to need booster shots to maintain the protection provided by vaccination. The COVID-19 vaccines are still working but staying up to date on booster doses helps restore this protection that can decrease over time. What is the difference between the updated COVID-19 bivalent boosters and the initial COVID-19 vaccines and boosters? The initial COVID-19 vaccines were made to protect against the original COVID-19 strain. They are considered monovalent vaccines because they target one strain of the virus. The COVID-19 bivalent booster vaccines target both the original type of COVID- 19 and the recent Omicron variant, specifically the BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants. The updated COVID-19 booster provides better protection against the strains of COVID-19 that are currently circulating. This is similar to flu vaccines, which are updated each year to target specific newer strains of the flu that are expected to spread. Are there side effects associated with the booster dose? Reactions reported after the booster dose are similar to those of the primary series: most often, pain at the injection site, fatigue, headache, and fever. Most side effects are mild to moderate and go away in a few days. As with the primary vaccine series, serious side effects are rare. COVID-19 at-home test kits available (as supplies last) PWHD Update Information Monday 2022 The Prince William Health District What You Should Know You can avoid a fright this Halloween by making sure your trick-or-treaters are safe. Check Your Kids Treats Homemade is not preferred. Parents are advised to only allow children to eat candy that has been pre-packaged by a reputable manufacturer. Check wrapped treats for signs of tampering. Throw away anything that is discolored, has tiny pinholes or that has a torn wrapper. Illegal drugs may be made look like popular candy brands; these are known as "look-alikes." If you suspect your child's candy contains illicit or illegal substances, call your local police department. Pets like candy too. Many candy items, including chocolate, are poisonous to pets. Use this as a chance to teach children about pet safety and the need to properly store candy. Lock your stock. Locked medicine cabinets keep look-alike prescriptions and over-the-counter medications away from children who can easily mistake them for candy. If your child has a food allergy, check the label to ensure the allergen isn't present. Do not allow the child to eat any home-baked goods he or she may have received. If you have very young children, be sure to remove any choking hazards such as gum, peanuts, hard candies, or small toys. Call the Poison Control Hotline (1-800-222-1222) to report any incidents and receive trained medical advice. Officials also recommend putting the number in all family cell phones as well as programming it as a speed dial number on landlines and posting the number near house phones. Medical professionals including physicians, registered nurses and pharmacists offer confidential advice on poison emergencies, poison prevention, drug information, food poisoning, animal bites and more. They are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Trick-or-Treating Healthy Reminders Stay home if you're sick and stay away from those who are ill. Children shouldn't snack on treats from their goody bags while they're out trick- or-treating. Give them a light meal or snack before they head out - don't send them out on an empty stomach. Urge them to wait until they get home and let you inspect their loot before they eat any of it. Prepare your trick-or-treater with trick-or-treat safety items: a flashlight, reflective tape or strips applied to costumes and candy bags, and an emergency contact information card in case they get lost or separated from the group. Trick or treat as part of a large group with a responsible adult. Walk on sidewalks whenever possible, or on the far edge of the road facing traffic to stay safe. Look both ways before crossing the street at a crosswalk or intersection. Walk, don't run between houses to avoid trips and falls. Keep your hands clean by using hand sanitizer. If you're giving out candy, wash your hands frequently. Never take candy from strangers. Parents should only allow kids to go to homes in which they know the residents. Costumes Do not wear decorative contact lenses without a prescription. Decorative lenses purchased without a prescription may not fit properly, leaving the eye more susceptible to scratches on the outer layer of the eye, or getting an ulcer (an open sore) on the cornea—the clear covering over the front of the eye. Painting your face can be a fun alternative to wearing a mask. Test novelty makeups in a small area on the arm to test for an allergic reaction before applying it to your face. Remove all makeup according to the manufacturers' instructions before bedtime to prevent possible skin and eye irritation. Make sure costumes fit well to avoid blocked vision and help prevent trips and falls. Choose costume accessories that are short, soft, and flexible. Choose items that are made of materials such as plastic or foam. It is possible to be infected with a flu virus and the virus that causes COVID-19 at the same time. Some symptoms of flu and COVID-19 are similar. Virginia is experiencing early flu and flu-like illness activity. This year's flu season is already showing concerning, early signs that it may be worse than in recent years. o More people are seeking care in hospitals and urgent care centers for influenza-like illness compared to the same time in previous years, particularly young children aged 0- 4 years. Virginia health officials encourage everyone aged six months and older, with rare exceptions, to get a flu vaccine this fall. Flu vaccination provides the best protection against flu. Vaccination reduces flu illnesses, as well as hospitalizations and deaths due to flu. The flu vaccine protects people and their communities. To find vaccine locations, vaccinate.virginia.gov or call 877-VAX-IN-VA (877-829- 4682, TTY users call 7-1-1).
